MATERIAL CHANGES
This section revises procedures for developing the issues to be covered in a regulation project formerly contained in Part 30, and in memoranda, guides, and other Chief Counsel documents.
This section supersedes CCDM 32.1.3, dated April 11, 2004.

Upon assignment to a project, drafting team should prepare a time line setting interim goal dates designed ensure that the project meets its set completion date. The time line should include deadlines for required administrative procedures; the preparation of issues memorandum and drafts of the guidance; front office brieﬁngs and, to the extent necessary, brieﬁngs with the Chief Counsel (or a Deputy Chief Counsel) and Treasury personnel. for a discussion of Milestones. (

) Once the decision has been made to issue guidance on an issue, the Associate assigns the project to a drafting team consisting, at a minimum, of Team branch attorney and reviewer. The drafting team is responsible for with the requirements for processing and publishing a regulation and the re- quirements imposed by Federal administrative law. (

) The drafting team must check LEXIS or Westlaw to determine if any other regulations are affected by the regulation project so that the other can be changed if necessary and to determine if any form of other guidance needs to be changed because of the regulation project. (

) The drafting team should conduct thorough research. When developing the substantive issues in a regulation project, the drafting team should consult following sources: • Statutes, including newly enacted provisions and related provisions • Legislative history, particularly House Ways and Means and Senate Finance Committees, and Conference Reports • General explanation of a particular tax act prepared by the staff of Joint Committee on Taxation (Blue Book) • Case law, including briefs • Published guidance and background ﬁles, and other IRS documents (including PLRs, TAMs, and GCMs) • Law review articles and articles in other periodicals • IRS and Treasury personnel • Public comments received on an NPRM, including at any public or public meetings • Taxpayer and practitioner questions and inquiries (
) The drafting team should be aware of any effective date issues. Section

(b) of the Code contains rules regarding the authority of the Treasury the IRS to issue retroactive regulations. The statutory effective date must be considered when issuing regulations on a newly enacted statutory provision. (

) In some cases, the drafting team may need to prepare a formal issues randum to assist the Chief Counsel, the Associate Chief Counsel, or in making the necessary technical and policy decisions. The memorandum should identify the signiﬁcant issues raised in the project and should include analysis and recommended resolution. The drafting team should present native and opposing positions in the issues memorandum. (
